options.A: mother brought her 2-month-old baby with seizures and a history of the same seizures in his older brother. The seizures resolved at 8 months of age. What is the likely gene involved?

question_text: What is the channel involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME)?

options.A: Sodium (Na)

options.A: LGI-1

Tuberous sclerosis
IV Diazepam

question_text: In a case involving Landau-Kleffner syndrome (verbal auditory agnosia and progressive aphasia) who was found to have electrographic seizures during sleep on EEG, what is the diagnosis?

options.A: Landau-Kleffner syndrome (LKS)

question_text: In a patient with developmental delay and multiple seizure types (tonic spasms, drop attacks), what is the finding on EEG?

options.A: Spike and slow waves slower than 2 Hz

question_text: In a normal child with a simple febrile seizure, what is the risk of developing epilepsy?
In a scenario where an infant with myoclonus started focally and became progressive, what would you expect to see on EEG?

options.A: Burst suppression

question_text: In the same scenario of the young lady post-aneurysm clipping, what is the recommended antiepileptic drug (AED) to use?  [Implicit scenario involves post-SAH/clipping seizure]

options.A: Keppra
patient experiences a visual aura lasting for 10 seconds followed by a headache. What is the most likely explanation for this phenomenon?
young lady who underwent tumor resection presents with a staring spell and loss of awareness. EEG shows frontal discharges. What is the classification of her seizure?

question_text: Patient with absence seizure; what is the medication that worsens the seizure?

options.A: Oxycarbazepine
patient presents with a figure of 4, fencing posture, and right side nose rubbing. Which localization is most likely?

question_text: In a case scenario of a patient with Mesial Temporal Lobe Epilepsy (MTLE) on two sufficient anti-seizure medications, but still experiencing monthly seizures, what is the next step?

options.A: Start workup for epilepsy surgery
options.C: Increase the dose of current anti-seizure medications
options.D: Recommend lifestyle modifications and stress reduction

question_text: An elderly patient with a history of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoporosis presents with seizures. Which medication is commonly used for seizure management in this patient?

options.A: Valproate
patient with partial seizures has a PET scan showing hypometabolism in the perisylvian region. Which receptor is most likely involved?
